paper_title: Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles co-modified defective zeolite TS-1 for improved photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.llm generation: Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles co-modified defective zeolite TS-1
catalyst.source: Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles co-modified defective zeolite TS-1 for improved photocatalytic CO2 reduction
catalyst.context: Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles co-modified defective zeolite TS-1 for improved photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.source: Herein, Ag and TiO 2 nanoparticles co-loaded zeolite TS-1 (Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1) were synthesized by the ion-exchange and subsequently in-situ photodeposition method.
catalyst.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into fuels has been an attractive research topic.Herein, Ag and TiO 2 nanoparticles co-loaded zeolite TS-1 (Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1) were synthesized by the ion-exchange and subsequently in-situ photodeposition method.The obtained Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 sample has a high surface area and rich Ti 3 -V o defects and as well as highly dispersed Ag nanoparticles.As expected, the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 not only shows high CO 2 adsorption capacity, but also improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.As a result, only CO and CH 4 can be detected on the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 in the photocatalytic CO 2 conversion, and the competing H 2 evolution can be completely suppressed, suggestive of its high selectivity.The super photocatalytic activity toward CO 2 reduction can be ascribed to the synergistic effect among highly dispersed Ag nanoparticle, the support zeolite TS-1 and TiO 2 with highly exposed 101 planes.

catalyst.source: The final sample TiO 2 /TS-1 with different Ti content can be obtained.
catalyst.context: Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt) was purchased from Shanghai JK, China.Silicic acid hydrate(H 2 SiO 3 , CR), titanium sulfate (Ti(SO 4 ) 2 , CR), sodium carbonate (Na 2 CO 3 , CR), PVP (K-40), glycol, methyl alcohol (CH 3 OH) and silver nitrate (AgNO 3 , CR) were provided from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd without further purification in this work. Zeolite TS-1 was prepared by a hydrothermal crystalline process.Typically, 0.08 g Na 2 CO 3 and 0.02 g KCl were dissolved into a mixture solution including 8 mL H 2 O and 12 g TPAOH.Subsequently, 50 mmol H 2 SiO 3 was slowly added into the above solution and stirred for 6 h at 40 C.Then, the mixed solution consisting of 2 mmol Ti(SO 4 ) 2 was also added into the above solution and vigorously stirred at 40 C for 4 h.Next, the resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon autoclave and treated at 160 C for 16 h.After, the solution was cooled to room temperature and washed three times with ethanol and distilled water.The final powder sample was collected after drying at 100 C overnight and calcination at 550 C for 4 h. 500 mg powder sample TS-1 was added into 20 mL Ti(SO 4 ) 2 aqueous solution with different concentration (0.1 M, 0.2 M and 0.3 M) and stirred at 80 C for 4 h, then the solution was washed three times with distilled water.Then, the sample was dried at 100 C overnight and calcined at 550 C for 4 h.The final sample TiO 2 /TS-1 with different Ti content can be obtained. 1 mL AgNO 3 aqueous solution (0.05 M, 0.1 M, 0.15 M and 0.2 M) was injected into the TiO 2 /TS-1 suspension aqueous solution (0.5 g, 100 mL) and stirred for 20 min, then the solution was irradiated for 30 min under UV light and CH 3 OH as sacrificial agent was added in to the mixed solution.After being filtered and washed by water and ethanol, the precipitate was freeze dried overnight and the final samples Ag-TiO 2 /TSwith different Ag contents were obtained. 50 mmol Ti(SO 4 ) 2 was added into 20 mL aqueous solution and stirred at 80 C for 4 h, then the solution was treated at 150 C for 16 h.After, the solution was washed several times with distilled water.The final powder sample was collected after drying at 100 C overnight and calcination at 550 C for 4 h. The wide-angle X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were measured on a Rigaku D/Max 2200PC diffractometer with Cu K radiation (40 kV and 40 mA).The nitrogen sorption/desorption curves of the samples were tested on Micromeritics ASAP 3020, and the specific surface area and the pore size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods at -196 C, respectively.The morphologies and structure of samples were investigated by the Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM, JEOL-2010 F operated at 200 kV) and Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FEI, Magellan 400) using an HAADF detector.The temperature-programed desorption with CO 2 (CO 2 -TPD) curves of the samples were conducted on Micrometrics Chemisorb 2750 instrument attached with ChemiSoft TPx software.The content of Ag was measured by using Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy analyzer (ICP-OES).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) peaks of Si, Ti, Ag and O elements were measured on the ESCAlab 250Xi instrument with the C 1 s electron peak (BE 284.8eV) as internal reference.UV visible absorption spectrum (UV-vis) was obtained on the Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer, and BaSO 4 was selected as the reference sample.Photoluminescence spectra (PL) of the samples were analyzed on the Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrometer with the excitation wavelength of nm.The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of the samples were measured on the Bruker EMXPLUS10/12 EPR electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer equipped with a Quanta-Ray Nd:YAG laser system. The photocurrent tests were performed on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system, and Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) was used as electrolyte.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as the light source.Pt sheet and Ag/AgCl were the opposite electrode and reference electrode, respectively.For preparing the work electrode, 40 mg catalyst and 10 mg carbon were ground and then dispersed into the mixed solution including 1 mL ethanol, 0.5 mL water and 0.2 mL Nafion solution (5) by ultrasonic technique to obtain catalyst slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 , followed by drying at 100 C for 4 h. The process of photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was examined in a Y. Sun et al. mL gas-closed system and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp.Typically, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 .Prior to irradiation, the photoreaction system was purged with the high-purity N 2 for 30 min to remove air and then purged with CO 2 gas for 30 min.Next, 1 mL distilled water was injected into the photoreaction system and initiated the photocatalytic reaction.The reduction products were collected at given intervals (1 h) and determined by a gas chromatography (Thermo Scientific TRACE 1300) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The apparent quantum efficiency (QE) was measured under the same photocatalytic reaction condition with irradiation light at 420 nm by using 300 W Xe lamp, and the QE was calculated according to Eq. ( 1): (1)

light source.source: As expected, the obtained sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 exhibits much excellent and stable photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance, giving a high production rate of 3.16 mol g -1 h -1 for CO and 0.47 mol g -1 h -1 for CH 4 under UV-vis light irradiation, especially, the production rate of CO and CH 4 is nearly unchanged after three cycles.
light source.context: The TiO 2 species and Ag nanoparticles are loaded on zeolite TS-1 by an ion-exchange and subsequently in-situ photodeposition methods.As expected, the obtained sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 exhibits much excellent and stable photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance, giving a high production rate of 3.16 mol g -1 h -1 for CO and 0.47 mol g -1 h -1 for CH 4 under UV-vis light irradiation, especially, the production rate of CO and CH 4 is nearly unchanged after three cycles.The super photocatalytic activity can be attributed to the jointed effect of the support zeolite, highly exposed reduction planes 101 of TiO 2 and uniformly dispersed Ag nanoparticles.The support with larger surface area and rich defects plays an important role in dispersing the active species and adsorbing CO 2 molecular as well as accelerating the separation of photogenerated charges by hole-electron traps.The highly exposed planes 101 of TiO 2 as reduction sites can accelerate the conversion of CO 2 .The highly dispersed Ag nanoparticles, as a cocatalyst, not only can significantly improve the CO 2 adsorption performance and the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, but also can produce hot electrons for CO 2 reduction.The synergetic effects among Ag, TS-1 and TiO 2 , jointly improve CO 2 adsorption performance and the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, which makes it show enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity. Yuanyuan Sun: Conceptualization, Methodology, Data curation, Software.Guohui Li: Methodology, Writing -original draft.Yun Gong: Investigation.Zhenfan Sun: Supervision.Heliang Yao: Software, Validation.Xiaoxia Zhou: Writing -review editing. Fig. 1.XRD patterns of the samples TS-1, TiO 2 /TS-1, Ag/TS-1 and Ag-TiO 2 / TS-1. Fig. 6.The signals for O1s, Ti 2p and Si 2p signals are observed on the sample TiO 2 /TS-1 while the signals for O1s, Ti 2p, Si 2p and Ag 3d are observed on the surface of the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 (Fig.6a).The highresolution XPS spectrum of Ag 3d shows two peaks of Ag 3d 5/2 and Ag 3d 3/2 at 367.8 and 373.8 eV, respectively, which could be ascribed to metal Ag (Fig.6b), besides, the doublet separation degree of Ag 3d is about 6.0 eV, further indicating that the existence of metal Ag(Wang et al., 2020).The Si 2p XPS spectra of the samples TiO 2 /TS-1 and Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 only shows a peak at 103.9 eV related to the Si-O species(Chao et al., 2011), as shown in Fig.6c.The O 1s spectrum can be deconvoluted into two peaks at 530.1 eV and 533.0 eV (Fig.6d), which are assigned to lattice oxygen (O L ) and chemical adsorbed oxygen (O C ), respectively(Hu et al., 2018).The existence of O C could be related to the Fig. 2. (a) The SEM, (b) HAADF and (c-f) high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1. Fig. 3.The (a) SEM images and (b-f) the corresponding element mapping images of Si, O, Ti and Ag for the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1. Fig. 4. (a) N 2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and (b) the corresponding pore size distribution of the samples TS-1, TiO 2 /TS-1, Ag/TS-1 and Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1. Fig. 5. (a) UV-vis adsorption spectra and (b) PL spectra of the samples TS-1, TiO 2 /TS-1, Ag/TS-1 and Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1. Fig. 6.(a) The survey spectrum, the XPS fine spectra of (b) Ag 3d, (c) Si 2p, d) O 1 s (e) Ti 2p and (f) EPR spectra for the samples TiO 2 /TS-1 and Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1. Fig. 7. (a) Transient photocurrent densities of the as-prepared sample electrodes at 0.2 V versus Ag/AgCl.(b) CO yield and (c) CH 4 yields of the as-prepared samples with different time under UV-vis light irradiation.(d-e) The CO and CH 4 yields on the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 with different Ti and Ag contents in 1 h under light irradiation.(f) The distribution of CO 2 reduction products over different samples (left: TiO 2 /TS-1, middle: Ag/TS-1, right: Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1).(g) The stability of the sample Ag-TiO 2 /TS-1 in the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction. Y.Sun et al. This research was sponsored by National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 51502330) and the Natural Science Foundation of Shanghai (19ZR1464500). The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.jhazmat.2020.124019.

lamp.source: A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as the light source.

lamp.source: The process of photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was examined in a Y. Sun et al. mL gas-closed system and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp.
lamp.context: Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt) was purchased from Shanghai JK, China.Silicic acid hydrate(H 2 SiO 3 , CR), titanium sulfate (Ti(SO 4 ) 2 , CR), sodium carbonate (Na 2 CO 3 , CR), PVP (K-40), glycol, methyl alcohol (CH 3 OH) and silver nitrate (AgNO 3 , CR) were provided from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd without further purification in this work. Zeolite TS-1 was prepared by a hydrothermal crystalline process.Typically, 0.08 g Na 2 CO 3 and 0.02 g KCl were dissolved into a mixture solution including 8 mL H 2 O and 12 g TPAOH.Subsequently, 50 mmol H 2 SiO 3 was slowly added into the above solution and stirred for 6 h at 40 C.Then, the mixed solution consisting of 2 mmol Ti(SO 4 ) 2 was also added into the above solution and vigorously stirred at 40 C for 4 h.Next, the resulting solution was transferred into a Teflon autoclave and treated at 160 C for 16 h.After, the solution was cooled to room temperature and washed three times with ethanol and distilled water.The final powder sample was collected after drying at 100 C overnight and calcination at 550 C for 4 h. 500 mg powder sample TS-1 was added into 20 mL Ti(SO 4 ) 2 aqueous solution with different concentration (0.1 M, 0.2 M and 0.3 M) and stirred at 80 C for 4 h, then the solution was washed three times with distilled water.Then, the sample was dried at 100 C overnight and calcined at 550 C for 4 h.The final sample TiO 2 /TS-1 with different Ti content can be obtained. 1 mL AgNO 3 aqueous solution (0.05 M, 0.1 M, 0.15 M and 0.2 M) was injected into the TiO 2 /TS-1 suspension aqueous solution (0.5 g, 100 mL) and stirred for 20 min, then the solution was irradiated for 30 min under UV light and CH 3 OH as sacrificial agent was added in to the mixed solution.After being filtered and washed by water and ethanol, the precipitate was freeze dried overnight and the final samples Ag-TiO 2 /TSwith different Ag contents were obtained. 50 mmol Ti(SO 4 ) 2 was added into 20 mL aqueous solution and stirred at 80 C for 4 h, then the solution was treated at 150 C for 16 h.After, the solution was washed several times with distilled water.The final powder sample was collected after drying at 100 C overnight and calcination at 550 C for 4 h. The wide-angle X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were measured on a Rigaku D/Max 2200PC diffractometer with Cu K radiation (40 kV and 40 mA).The nitrogen sorption/desorption curves of the samples were tested on Micromeritics ASAP 3020, and the specific surface area and the pore size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods at -196 C, respectively.The morphologies and structure of samples were investigated by the Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM, JEOL-2010 F operated at 200 kV) and Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FEI, Magellan 400) using an HAADF detector.The temperature-programed desorption with CO 2 (CO 2 -TPD) curves of the samples were conducted on Micrometrics Chemisorb 2750 instrument attached with ChemiSoft TPx software.The content of Ag was measured by using Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy analyzer (ICP-OES).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) peaks of Si, Ti, Ag and O elements were measured on the ESCAlab 250Xi instrument with the C 1 s electron peak (BE 284.8eV) as internal reference.UV visible absorption spectrum (UV-vis) was obtained on the Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer, and BaSO 4 was selected as the reference sample.Photoluminescence spectra (PL) of the samples were analyzed on the Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrometer with the excitation wavelength of nm.The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of the samples were measured on the Bruker EMXPLUS10/12 EPR electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer equipped with a Quanta-Ray Nd:YAG laser system. The photocurrent tests were performed on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system, and Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) was used as electrolyte.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as the light source.Pt sheet and Ag/AgCl were the opposite electrode and reference electrode, respectively.For preparing the work electrode, 40 mg catalyst and 10 mg carbon were ground and then dispersed into the mixed solution including 1 mL ethanol, 0.5 mL water and 0.2 mL Nafion solution (5) by ultrasonic technique to obtain catalyst slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 , followed by drying at 100 C for 4 h. The process of photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was examined in a Y. Sun et al. mL gas-closed system and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp.Typically, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 .Prior to irradiation, the photoreaction system was purged with the high-purity N 2 for 30 min to remove air and then purged with CO 2 gas for 30 min.Next, 1 mL distilled water was injected into the photoreaction system and initiated the photocatalytic reaction.The reduction products were collected at given intervals (1 h) and determined by a gas chromatography (Thermo Scientific TRACE 1300) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The apparent quantum efficiency (QE) was measured under the same photocatalytic reaction condition with irradiation light at 420 nm by using 300 W Xe lamp, and the QE was calculated according to Eq. ( 1): (1)

The process of photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was examined in a Y. Sun et al. mL gas-closed system and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp.Typically, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on FTO glass plate with an active area of 1 cm 2 .Prior to irradiation, the photoreaction system was purged with the high-purity N 2 for 30 min to remove air and then purged with CO 2 gas for 30 min.Next, 1 mL distilled water was injected into the photoreaction system and initiated the photocatalytic reaction.The reduction products were collected at given intervals (1 h) and determined by a gas chromatography (Thermo Scientific TRACE 1300) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The apparent quantum efficiency (QE) was measured under the same photocatalytic reaction condition with irradiation light at 420 nm by using 300 W Xe lamp, and the QE was calculated according to Eq. ( 1): (1)
